intro: Erophila americana var. bardinii, commonly known as the Bardini's erophila, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its opposite, lance-shaped leaves and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in wetlands. It blooms from late spring to early fall, producing vibrant pink to purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. This variety is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ecological benefits and adaptability to aquatic environments.
